Conventions

  • â€¢

    By Lie group, we mean either real or complex.

  • â€¢

    A closed Lie subgroup of a Lie group is a submanifold that is also a subgroup (see TheoremÂ 3).

  • â€¢

    A Lie subgroup is a subgroup that is also an immersed submanifold.

Chapter 1 Lie groups: basic definitions

We will have two notions of subgroups of Lie groups:

Definition 1.0.1.

Let GğºG be a complex or real Lie group and Hğ»H be a subgroup of GğºG.

  1. (i)

    Hğ»H is a Lie subgroup if it is an immersed submanifold of GğºG with the multiplication and inverse maps being smooth (or analytic).

  2. (ii)

    Hğ»H is a closed Lie subgroup if it is an embedded submanifold of GğºG.

Example 1.0.1.

Any of the classical Lie groups are closed Lie subgroups of GLâ¡(n,ğ•‚)GLğ‘›ğ•‚\operatorname{{\mathrm{GL}}}(n,\mathbb{K}). For a Lie subgroup that is not closed, consider the irrational winding on the torus, that is G=ğ•‹2=â„2/â„¤2ğºsuperscriptğ•‹2superscriptâ„2superscriptâ„¤2G=\mathbb{T}^{2}=\mathbb{R}^{2}/\mathbb{Z}^{2}, and H=fâ€‹(â„)ğ»ğ‘“â„H=f(\mathbb{R}) with fâ€‹(t,s)=(tmodâ„¤,Î±â€‹smodâ„¤)ğ‘“ğ‘¡ğ‘ moduloğ‘¡â„¤moduloğ›¼ğ‘ â„¤f(t,s)=(t\mod\mathbb{Z},\alpha s\mod\mathbb{Z}), where Î±âˆˆâ„\â„šğ›¼\â„â„š\alpha\in\mathbb{R}\backslash\mathbb{Q}.

1.1 Lie subgroups and quotients

The following theorem allows us to reduce the study of Lie groups to the study of finite groups and connected Lie groups, since G0subscriptğº0G_{0} is a normal subgroup of GğºG and G/G0ğºsubscriptğº0G/G_{0} is a discrete group. where G0superscriptğº0G^{0} is the identity component of GğºG.

Theorem 1 (Theorem 2.6, [Kir08]).

Let GğºG be a real or complex Lie group and G0superscriptğº0G^{0} its identity component. Then G0superscriptğº0G^{0} is a normal subgroup of GğºG and a Lie group itself, while G/G0ğºsuperscriptğº0G/G^{0} is a discrete group.

In fact, we can reduce the case of connected Lie groups to simply connected Lie groups:

Theorem 2 (Theorem 2.7, [Kir08]).

Let GğºG be a connected Lie group. Then its universal cover G~~ğº\tilde{G} has a canonical structure of a Lie group such that the covering map p:G~â†’G:ğ‘â†’~ğºğºp:\tilde{G}\to G is a homomorphism of Lie groups whose kernel is isomorphic to the fundamental group of GğºG. Moreover, in this case, kerâ¡pkernelğ‘\ker p is a discrete central subgroup in G~~ğº\tilde{G}.

Proof.

The lifting property of the universal cover implies that G~~ğº\tilde{G} is a Lie group. The kernel is discrete, being the fiber of a covering map. The fact that it is central follows from the more general fact that every discrete normal subgroup of a connected Lie group is central. To show the latter, one considers the map Gâ†’N,gâ†’gâ€‹nâ€‹gâˆ’1formulae-sequenceâ†’ğºğ‘â†’ğ‘”ğ‘”ğ‘›superscriptğ‘”1G\to N,g\to gng^{-1} where Nğ‘N is the normal subgroup and nâˆˆNğ‘›ğ‘n\in N is some fixed element. Then the inverse image of any element nâ€²âˆˆNsuperscriptğ‘›â€²ğ‘n^{\prime}\in N is closed an open in GğºG, so it is all of GğºG in the case where nâ€²=nsuperscriptğ‘›â€²ğ‘›n^{\prime}=n and empty otherwise. âˆ

Example 1.1.1.

We have the following connection between subgroups and Lie subgroups (i.e.Â subgroups that are also submanifolds):

Theorem 3 (Theorem 2.8, [Kir08]).
  1. (i)

    Any Lie subgroup of a Lie group is closed in the topology of the ambient group.

  2. (ii)

    Any closed subgroup of a Lie group is a real Lie subgroup.

Proof.

For the first part of the theorem, we note that HÂ¯Â¯ğ»\overline{H} is a subgroup of GğºG as well. We claim that Hğ»H (and thus Hâ€‹xğ»ğ‘¥Hx for every xâˆˆHÂ¯ğ‘¥Â¯ğ»x\in\overline{H} ) is open and dense in HÂ¯Â¯ğ»\overline{H}. To see this, note that eâˆˆHÂ¯ğ‘’Â¯ğ»e\in\overline{H} implies that for every neighborhood UâŠ†Gğ‘ˆğºU\subseteq G of eğ‘’e in GğºG, Uâˆ©Hğ‘ˆğ»U\cap H is nonempty. In particular there exists some open set Uğ‘ˆU in GğºG containing rğ‘Ÿr such that Uâˆ©Hâ‰ âˆ…ğ‘ˆğ»U\cap H\neq\emptyset. Then Uâˆ©Hğ‘ˆğ»U\cap H will be a neighborhood of eğ‘’e in HÂ¯Â¯ğ»\overline{H} and Hğ»H is open because it can be written as the union of all subsets of the form hâ€‹(Uâˆ©H)â„ğ‘ˆğ»h(U\cap H) for hâˆˆHâ„ğ»h\in H.

To conclude, note that for x,yâˆˆHÂ¯ğ‘¥ğ‘¦Â¯ğ»x,y\in\overline{H}, Hâ€‹xâˆ©Hâ€‹yğ»ğ‘¥ğ»ğ‘¦Hx\cap Hy is dense in HÂ¯Â¯ğ»\overline{H}, so it is nonempty. This implies that Hâ€‹x=Hâ€‹y=Hğ»ğ‘¥ğ»ğ‘¦ğ»Hx=Hy=H and Hğ»H thus H=HÂ¯ğ»Â¯ğ»H=\overline{H}. âˆ

Remark 2.1.3.

To motivate the term â€œinfinitesimal generatorsâ€, one can think of them as directions in which one can move from the identity (using the exponential map) in order to generate the whole group.

2.2 The commutator

In literature, one has at least three (and four in the case of vector fields) ways to define the commutator of some Lie group, Namely

  1. (i)

    Using left-invariant vector fields (see [Lee18]).

  2. (ii)

    As the lowest order term in the logarithm of the multiplication of exponentials (see LemmaÂ 2.2.1).

  3. (iii)

    As the differential of the adjoint representation.

  4. (iv)

    In the case of vector fields, as the differentiation of the second vector field along the first.

For completeness, we recall that in [Lee18], the commutator of a Lie group is defined as

[x,y]=[X,Y]eâ€‹Â forÂ â€‹x,yâˆˆğ”¤formulae-sequenceğ‘¥ğ‘¦subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘Œğ‘’Â forÂ ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ”¤[x,y]=[X,Y]_{e}\text{ for }x,y\in\mathfrak{g}

2.3 Subalgebras, ideals and center

Definition 2.3.1.

A subalgebra of a Lie algebra ğ”¤ğ”¤\mathfrak{g} is a subspace ğ”¥âŠ†ğ”¤ğ”¥ğ”¤\mathfrak{h}\subseteq\mathfrak{g} that is closed under the Lie bracket: [x,y]âˆˆğ”¥ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ”¥[x,y]\in\mathfrak{h} for all x,yâˆˆğ”¥ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ”¥x,y\in\mathfrak{h}. An ideal is a subalgebra ğ”¥ğ”¥\mathfrak{h} such that [x,y]âˆˆğ”¥ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ”¥[x,y]\in\mathfrak{h} for all xâˆˆğ”¥,yâˆˆğ”¤formulae-sequenceğ‘¥ğ”¥ğ‘¦ğ”¤x\in\mathfrak{h},y\in\mathfrak{g}.

It is easy to see that one can take quotients of Lie algebras by ideals and thus obtain Lie algebras.

The next theorem tells us that Lie subgroups correspond to subalgebras, and normal closed Lie subgroups correspond to ideals. In the case of the latter, a converse statement gives us a way to check if a subgroup is normal by checking whether the corresponding subalgebra is an ideal. In this way we obtain a link between an algebraic condition (being a normal subgroup) and a linear one (being an ideal).

Theorem 10 (Theorem 3.22, [Kir08]).

Let GğºG be a real or complex Lie group with Lie algebra ğ”¤ğ”¤\mathfrak{g}. Then

  1. (i)

    If Hğ»H is a Lie subgroup (not necessarily closed) of GğºG, then ğ”¥ğ”¥\mathfrak{h} is a subalgebra of ğ”¤ğ”¤\mathfrak{g}.

  2. (ii)

    If Hğ»H is a normal closed Lie subgroup of GğºG, then ğ”¥ğ”¥\mathfrak{h} is an ideal of ğ”¤ğ”¤\mathfrak{g}.

  3. (iii)

    If Hğ»H is a closed Lie subgroup of GğºG, both GğºG and Hğ»H are connected, then ğ”¥ğ”¥\mathfrak{h} is an ideal of ğ”¤ğ”¤\mathfrak{g} if and only if Hğ»H is a normal subgroup of GğºG.

For a manifold Mğ‘€M, the space Vectâ€‹(M)Vectğ‘€\mathrm{Vect}(M) can be made into a Lie algebra by directly defining the bracket of two vector fields and showing that it is skew-symmetric and bilinear. adğ”¤=ğ”¤/ğ”·(ğ”¤)=Im(ad:ğ”¤â†’ğ”¤ğ”©(ğ”¤)).\text{ad}\,\mathfrak{g}=\mathfrak{g}/\mathfrak{z}(\mathfrak{g})=\text{Im}(\text{ad}:\mathfrak{g}\rightarrow\mathfrak{gl}(\mathfrak{g})).

2.6 Campbellâ€“Hausdorff formula

So far, we have shown that the multiplication in a Lie group GğºG defines the commutator in g=T1â€‹Gğ‘”subscriptğ‘‡1ğºg=T_{1}G. However, the definition of commutator only used the lowest non-trivial term of the group law in logarithmic coordinates. Thus, it might be expected that higher terms give more operations on g. However, it turns out that it is not so: the whole group law is completely determined by the lowest term, i.e.Â by the commutator, as follows from the Campbellâ€“Hausdorff formula:

Theorem 13 (Campbellâ€“Hausdorff Formula).

For small enough x,yâˆˆğ”¤ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ”¤x,y\in\mathfrak{g} one has

expâ¡(x)â€‹expâ¡(y)=expâ¡(Î¼â€‹(x,y))ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğœ‡ğ‘¥ğ‘¦\exp(x)\exp(y)=\exp(\mu(x,y))

for some ğ”¤ğ”¤\mathfrak{g}-valued function Î¼â€‹(x,y)ğœ‡ğ‘¥ğ‘¦\mu(x,y) which is given by the following series convergent in some neighborhood of (0,0)00(0,0):

Î¼â€‹(x,y)=x+y+âˆ‘nâ‰¥2Î¼nâ€‹(x,y),ğœ‡ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘¥ğ‘¦subscriptğ‘›2subscriptğœ‡ğ‘›ğ‘¥ğ‘¦\mu(x,y)=x+y+\sum_{n\geq 2}\mu_{n}(x,y),

where Î¼nâ€‹(x,y)subscriptğœ‡ğ‘›ğ‘¥ğ‘¦\mu_{n}(x,y) is a Lie polynomial in x,yğ‘¥ğ‘¦x,y of degree nğ‘›n, i.e. an expression consisting of commutators of x,yğ‘¥ğ‘¦x,y, their commutators, etc., of total degree nğ‘›n in x,yğ‘¥ğ‘¦x,y. This expression is universal: it does not depend on the Lie algebra ğ”¤ğ”¤\mathfrak{g} or on the choice of x,yğ‘¥ğ‘¦x,y. In particular, the group operation in a connected Lie group GğºG can be recovered from the commutator in ğ”¤ğ”¤\mathfrak{g}.

It is possible to write the expression for Î¼ğœ‡\mu explicitly. However, this is rarely useful, so we will only write the first few terms:

Î¼â€‹(x,y)=x+y+12â€‹[x,y]+112â€‹([x,[x,y]]+[y,[y,x]])+â‹¯ğœ‡ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘¥ğ‘¦12ğ‘¥ğ‘¦112ğ‘¥ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘¦ğ‘¦ğ‘¥â‹¯\mu(x,y)=x+y+\frac{1}{2}[x,y]+\frac{1}{12}\left([x,[x,y]]+[y,[y,x]]\right)+\cdots

Although it follows from the Campbellâ€“Hausdorff formula, the commutation criterion of the exponential can be also proven directly:

Theorem 14 (Theorem 3.36, [Kir08]).

Let x,yâˆˆğ”¤ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ”¤x,y\in\mathfrak{g}. Then exâ€‹ey=eyâ€‹exsuperscriptğ‘’ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘’ğ‘¦superscriptğ‘’ğ‘¦superscriptğ‘’ğ‘¥e^{x}e^{y}=e^{y}e^{x} if and only if [x,y]=0ğ‘¥ğ‘¦0[x,y]=0. Proof.

The if direction follows from the definition of the commutator via Taylor series. For the other direction we follow the method suggested in Exercise 3.11 of [Kir08]:

Adâ¡(ex)â€‹y=eadâ¡xâ€‹y=âˆ‘nâ‰¥0(adâ¡x)nn!â€‹y=yAdsuperscriptğ‘’ğ‘¥ğ‘¦superscriptğ‘’adğ‘¥ğ‘¦subscriptğ‘›0superscriptadğ‘¥ğ‘›ğ‘›ğ‘¦ğ‘¦\operatorname{Ad}(e^{x})y=e^{\operatorname{ad}x}y=\sum_{n\geq 0}\frac{(\operatorname{ad}x)^{n}}{n!}y=y

2.7 Fundamental theorems of Lie theory

Let us summarize the results we have so far about the relation between Lie groups and Lie algebras.

  1. 1.

    Every real or complex Lie group GğºG defines a Lie algebra ğ”¤=T1â€‹Gğ”¤subscriptğ‘‡1ğº\mathfrak{g}=T_{1}G (respectively, real or complex), with commutator defined by (3.2); we will write ğ”¤=Lieâ€‹(G)ğ”¤Lieğº\mathfrak{g}=\text{Lie}(G). Every morphism of Lie groups Ï†:G1â†’G2:ğœ‘â†’subscriptğº1subscriptğº2\varphi:G_{1}\to G_{2} defines a morphism of Lie algebras Ï†âˆ—:ğ”¤1â†’ğ”¤2:subscriptğœ‘â†’subscriptğ”¤1subscriptğ”¤2\varphi_{*}:\mathfrak{g}_{1}\to\mathfrak{g}_{2}. For connected G1subscriptğº1G_{1}, the map

    Homâ€‹(G1,G2)â†’Homâ€‹(ğ”¤1,ğ”¤2)â†’Homsubscriptğº1subscriptğº2Homsubscriptğ”¤1subscriptğ”¤2\text{Hom}(G_{1},G_{2})\to\text{Hom}(\mathfrak{g}_{1},\mathfrak{g}_{2})
    Ï†â†¦Ï†âˆ—maps-toğœ‘subscriptğœ‘\varphi\mapsto\varphi_{*}

    is injective. (Here Homâ€‹(ğ”¤1,ğ”¤2)Homsubscriptğ”¤1subscriptğ”¤2\text{Hom}(\mathfrak{g}_{1},\mathfrak{g}_{2}) is the set of Lie algebra morphisms.)

  2. 2.

    As a special case of the previous, every Lie subgroup HâŠ‚Gğ»ğºH\subset G defines a Lie subalgebra ğ”¥âŠ‚ğ”¤ğ”¥ğ”¤\mathfrak{h}\subset\mathfrak{g}.

  3. 3.

    The group law in a connected Lie group GğºG can be recovered from the commutator in ğ”¤ğ”¤\mathfrak{g}; however, we do not yet know whether we can also recover the topology of GğºG from ğ”¤ğ”¤\mathfrak{g}.

However, this still leaves a number of questions.

Question 1.

Given a morphism of Lie algebras ğ”¤1â†’ğ”¤2â†’subscriptğ”¤1subscriptğ”¤2\mathfrak{g}_{1}\to\mathfrak{g}_{2}, where ğ”¤1=Lieâ€‹(G1)subscriptğ”¤1Liesubscriptğº1\mathfrak{g}_{1}=\text{Lie}(G_{1}), ğ”¤2=Lieâ€‹(G2)subscriptğ”¤2Liesubscriptğº2\mathfrak{g}_{2}=\text{Lie}(G_{2}), can this morphism always be lifted to a morphism of the Lie groups?

Question 2.

Given a Lie subalgebra ğ”¥âŠ‚ğ”¤=Lieâ€‹(G)ğ”¥ğ”¤Lieğº\mathfrak{h}\subset\mathfrak{g}=\text{Lie}(G), does there always exist a corresponding Lie subgroup HâŠ‚Gğ»ğºH\subset G?

Question 3.

Can every Lie algebra be obtained as a Lie algebra of a Lie group?

As the following example shows, in this form the answer to question 1 is negative.

Example 2.7.1.

Let G1=S1=â„/â„¤,G2=â„formulae-sequencesubscriptğº1superscriptğ‘†1â„â„¤subscriptğº2â„G_{1}=S^{1}=\mathbb{R}/\mathbb{Z},G_{2}=\mathbb{R}. Then the Lie algebras are ğ”¤1=ğ”¤2=â„subscriptğ”¤1subscriptğ”¤2â„\mathfrak{g}_{1}=\mathfrak{g}_{2}=\mathbb{R} with zero commutator. Consider the identity map ğ”¤1â†’ğ”¤2:aâ†¦a:â†’subscriptğ”¤1subscriptğ”¤2maps-toğ‘ğ‘\mathfrak{g}_{1}\to\mathfrak{g}_{2}:a\mapsto a. Then the lift f~:â„â†’â„:~ğ‘“â†’â„â„\tilde{f}:\mathbb{R}\to\mathbb{R} of the corresponding morphism to the universal covering group (provided that the underlying morphism f:ğ•Š1â†’â„:ğ‘“â†’superscriptğ•Š1â„f:\mathbb{S}^{1}\to\mathbb{R} exists), should be given by (~Î¸)=Î¸+c\tilde{(}\theta)=\theta+c; on the other hand, it must also satisfy f~â€‹(â„¤)={0}~ğ‘“â„¤0\tilde{f}(\mathbb{Z})=\{0\}. Thus, this morphism of Lie algebras can not be lifted to a morphism of Lie groups.

In this example the difficulty arose because G1subscriptğº1G_{1} was not simply-connected. It turns out that this is the only difficulty: after taking care of this, the answers to all the questions posed above are positive. The following theorems give precise statements.

Theorem 15 (First fundemental theorem of Lie theory).

For any real or complex Lie group GğºG, there is a bijection between connected Lie subgroups HâŠ‚Gğ»ğºH\subset G and Lie subalgebras ğ”¥âŠ‚ğ”¤ğ”¥ğ”¤\mathfrak{h}\subset\mathfrak{g}, given by Hâ†¦ğ”¥=Lieâ€‹(H)=T1â€‹Hmaps-toğ»ğ”¥Lieğ»subscriptğ‘‡1ğ»H\mapsto\mathfrak{h}=\text{Lie}(H)=T_{1}H.

Theorem 16 (Second fundemental theorem of Lie theory).

If G1,G2subscriptğº1subscriptğº2G_{1},G_{2} are Lie groups (real or complex) and G1subscriptğº1G_{1} is connected and simply connected, then Homâ€‹(G1,G2)=Homâ€‹(ğ”¤1,ğ”¤2)Homsubscriptğº1subscriptğº2Homsubscriptğ”¤1subscriptğ”¤2\text{Hom}(G_{1},G_{2})=\text{Hom}(\mathfrak{g}_{1},\mathfrak{g}_{2}), where ğ”¤1,ğ”¤2subscriptğ”¤1subscriptğ”¤2\mathfrak{g}_{1},\mathfrak{g}_{2} are Lie algebras of G1,G2subscriptğº1subscriptğº2G_{1},G_{2} respectively.

Theorem 17 (Lieâ€™s third theorem).

Any finite-dimensional real or complex Lie algebra is isomorphic to a Lie algebra of a Lie group (respectively, real or complex).

These are the fundamental theorems of Lie theory and combining these with the previous results, we get the following important corollary.

Corollary 2.7.1 (Le group and algebra equivalence).

The categories of finite-dimensional Lie algebras and connected, simply-connected Lie groups are equivalent. In other words, for any real or complex finite-dimensional Lie algebra ğ”¤ğ”¤\mathfrak{g}, there is a unique (up to isomorphism) connected simply-connected Lie group GğºG (respectively, real or complex) with Lieâ€‹(G)=ğ”¤Lieğºğ”¤\text{Lie}(G)=\mathfrak{g}. Any other connected Lie group Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime} with Lie algebra ğ”¤ğ”¤\mathfrak{g} must be of the form G/Zğºğ‘G/Z for some discrete central subgroup ZâŠ‚Gğ‘ğºZ\subset G.

A.2 Universal covering

In this section we will be concerned with proving that under mild conditions, a space has a universal covering, i.e.Â a simply connected covering space.

Assumption 1.

We consider a topological space Xğ‘‹X that will be path-connected, locally connected and semi-locally simply connected.

While the first two assummptions may seem rather natural, we will now explain the third one.

Definition A.2.1.

A space Xğ‘‹X is semi-locally simply connected if for every xâˆˆXğ‘¥ğ‘‹x\in X there exists an open neighborhood Uğ‘ˆU of xğ‘¥x such that every loop in Uğ‘ˆU based at xğ‘¥x is homotopic in Xğ‘‹X to a constant loop in Uğ‘ˆU. In other words, the homomorphism

induced by the inclusion is trivial.

To motivate this assumption, we note that it is necessary for the existence of a universal covering. Indeed, if p:X~â†’X:ğ‘â†’~ğ‘‹ğ‘‹p:\tilde{X}\to X is a universal covering, x0âˆˆXsubscriptğ‘¥0ğ‘‹x_{0}\in X and Uğ‘ˆU an evenly covered neighborhood of x0subscriptğ‘¥0x_{0}, then any loop in Uğ‘ˆU based at xğ‘¥x lifts to a loop in X~~ğ‘‹\tilde{X} based at some x~0subscript~ğ‘¥0\tilde{x}_{0}.
